title: Geography and gender 'stack the deck' against the poorest in the world, Bill Gates warns
text:
Women in sub Saharan Africa have two years less education than men, do three times more unpaid labour and are less likely to be in the workplace - Â© 2018 Simon Townsley Ltd

Aid spending on health and education should be targeted at girls and countries where the gender equality gap is greatest, Bill Gates has said.

A report by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation tracking progress against the Sustainable Development Goals - a range of indicators in areas such as health and education agreed by every country in the world in 2015 - has highlighted the gender inequality which means that a girl born in a poor part of the world will face almost insurmountable barriers throughout her life.

It focuses on how “geography and gender stack the deck for or against” everyone at birth. The report says that aid investments in health and education - also known as human capital - should be targeted at girls and those “countries and districts that have to make up the most ground”.

The Goalkeepers 2019 report shows that the world has made good progress against two of the goals - cutting child mortality and increasing the number of years schooling the world’s children undertake.

But the world is off track on nearly every indicator the report looks at - particularly in terms of beating the world’s three biggest infectious disease killers, HIV, tuberculosis and malaria.

Mr Gates, founder of Microsoft and one of the world's richest men, said: “Almost half a billion people live in communities without access to health and education. Where you’re born and what gender you are has a major effect on this global inequality.”

The report, launched as the leaders of the world gather at the United Nations General Assembly in New York this week, highlights Chad, in the Sahel region of Africa, a country where more children die in a single day than in a whole year in Finland.

But a girl born in Chad faces even greater hurdles: in the womb and as a young baby she is unlikely to have got the right nutrients to help her develop which means she may be stunted; she probably cannot read or write and is likely to have been pregnant by the time she is 20.

The report says: “She deserves a better life. And we believe she can have one, as long as the world understands the many challenges she faces and gets to work on addressing them.”

The report shows how in Sub Saharan Africa girls undertake two years less education than boys, do three times more unpaid work than boys and are less likely to be in the workplace - there are 24 per cent more men in the workforce than women.
